repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This PR adds support for alternative definition of optional [1] type.

Partially implements #6254

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/typing.html#typing.Optional

comment_data.body:
Unless there's a good reason for this that I'm missing, I'd declare this with all the other builtin types in Cython/Compiler/Builtins.py.

It isn't obvious to me where the `__bool__` overload is actually used?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4773,6 +4783,14 @@ def specialize_here(self, pos, env, template_values=None):
         # Replace this type with the actual 'template' argument.
         return template_values[0].resolve()
 
+class PyNoneType(BuiltinObjectType):

comment_data.body: Doesn't this allow code like `cdef None x` or `x: None = 25` ? It seems to me that `Optional[]` or `Union[]` might just be special enough to specifically look for `None` in their type arguments rather than treating `None` as a type generally. `None` really isn't a type, it's a value that is allowed by the type system for practical syntax purposes (because writing `NoneType` would be awkward).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1277,6 +1277,9 @@ def coerce_to(self, dst_type, env):
             error(self.pos, "Cannot assign None to %s" % dst_type)
         return super().coerce_to(dst_type, env)
 
+    def analyse_as_type(self, env):
+        return py_none_type
+

comment_data.body:
`is_optional()` feels unclear to me as a name. It doesn't strictly refer to `typing.Optional`, just to something that is "optional" in whatever way.

Isn't a name like `allows_none` more concrete for the purpose?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4707,6 +4707,13 @@ class PythonTypeConstructorMixin:
     """Used to help Cython interpret indexed types from the typing module (or similar)
     """
     modifier_name = None
+    contains_none = False
+
+    def is_optional(self):

comment_data.body:
> Doesn't this allow code like `cdef None x` or `x: None = 25` ?

`cdef None` is not allowed even in this PR - I can add test for that if needed:
```
(cython311) root@c113a6388b51:~/dev/cython/test# cat aa.pyx
cdef None x
(cython311) root@c113a6388b51:~/dev/cython/test# cython -3 aa.pyx

Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
cdef None x
     ^
------------------------------------------------------------

aa.pyx:1:5: 'None' is not a type identifier
```
And `x: None` is already allowed in master (I suspect it fallbacks to `object`)

> It seems to me that Optional[] or Union[] might just be special enough to specifically look for None in their type arguments rather than treating None as a type generally. 

We need to have `None` type here to distinguish two cases:
1. `None` value in type definition (e.g. `Union[None, ExtentionType]`) and
2.  unknown type (e.g. `Union[ExtentionType, NonExistingType]`) - in this case we are having `None` value in `specialize_here()` function:

https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6333/files#diff-7f63ffd84e67d3d113d7ad10fa110111c779a8ca5edd7e12dc51097b36405eabR4773-R4785

> None really isn't a type

I don't fully agree. There is `None` type but is not part of public CAPI [1] of python (and this PR it uses just internal representation of this type - not using python CAPI):
```
>>> type(None)
<class 'NoneType'>
```

In general, I am using `None` type only to distinguish `None` in type from unknown type. (Moreover it makes sense to me to use type for `None`) If there is better/other solution I am fine to change the approach.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/none.html
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1277,6 +1277,9 @@ def coerce_to(self, dst_type, env):
             error(self.pos, "Cannot assign None to %s" % dst_type)
         return super().coerce_to(dst_type, env)
 
+    def analyse_as_type(self, env):
+        return py_none_type
+

comment_data.body:
> Isn't a name like allows_none more concrete for the purpose?

I am not good in naming things so I am totally fine on whatever has consensus among Core devs.

@@ -4707,6 +4707,13 @@ class PythonTypeConstructorMixin:
     """Used to help Cython interpret indexed types from the typing module (or similar)
     """

comment_data.body:
> Unless there's a good reason for this that I'm missing, I'd declare this with all the other builtin types in Cython/Compiler/Builtins.py.

No reason except that I am still newbie in Cython codebase. I will move it.

> It isn't obvious to me where the `__bool__` overload is actually used?

In cython code there are parts where  you have line `if typevar:` (at least in code analysing binary operators or assignment) where in master `typevar` contains `None` but in this PR it is `PyNoneType`. `__bool__` ensures the `if` statements will be evaluated in the same way than before. If you want concrete example just comment out `__bool__` method and run tests - you will get test failures.

         # Replace this type with the actual 'template' argument.
         return template_values[0].resolve()
 
+class PyNoneType(BuiltinObjectType):

> In cython code there are parts where you have line `if typevar:`

E.g. this line code:
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/7e2cd6ad57c9eeb1fc6bf5d2bea469888a3f9b61/Cython/Compiler/ExprNodes.py#L12142

comment_data.body:
> `if type1 and ...`

Typically that'd be testing that `type1 is not None` which would mean it hasn't yet been analysed. That's different from "`type1` has been analysed and is known to be none_type".

I'll have a proper look later this week and try to understand where that's making a difference.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4773,6 +4783,14 @@ def specialize_here(self, pos, env, template_values=None):
         # Replace this type with the actual 'template' argument.
         return template_values[0].resolve()
 
+class PyNoneType(BuiltinObjectType):

comment_data.body:
If we find `None` in code, we don't replace it with `None` as value, but with a `NoneNode`. That makes it easy to distinguish from the value `None` (as in "no node").

As you correctly wrote, the Python type is called `NoneType`, not `None`. The fact that Python uses `None` in the type system instead is simply that for users, typing `NoneType` is very unusual. Many programmers probably have never seen it but know `None` only as a constant value. Thus, `None` is ubiquitous and easy to read and understand as part of a type annotation – it allows `None` as a value, thus making the typed value optional.

However, that doesn't mean that `None` *is* a type, or that we have to represent it as a type in Cython. Just check the type declaration node for `node.is_none` to see if we found `None` in the source code.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1277,6 +1277,9 @@ def coerce_to(self, dst_type, env):
             error(self.pos, "Cannot assign None to %s" % dst_type)
         return super().coerce_to(dst_type, env)
 
+    def analyse_as_type(self, env):
+        return py_none_type
+

comment_data.body:
> However, that doesn't mean that `None` _is_ a type, or that we have to represent it as a type in Cython. Just check the type declaration node for `node.is_none` to see if we found `None` in the source code.

The core of this PR is following part:

```python
    def specialize_here(self, pos, env, template_values=None):
        if py_none_type in template_values:
            self.contains_none = True
```
https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6333/files#diff-7f63ffd84e67d3d113d7ad10fa110111c779a8ca5edd7e12dc51097b36405eabR4782-R4784

Here, we are detecting whether annotation contains `None` (E.g. `Union[XYZ, None]`). I double checked it and without introducing `NoneType`, this code gets literal `None` value for both cases:

* `Union[int, None]`
* `Union[int, DummyType]`

Hence, without further changes I **cannot** distinguish following cases:
1. non-recognized type - in this case we should evaluate annotation as `object`
2. `None` value - in this case the type is candidate for evaluation of optional type - e.g. `Union[]`

> [!NOTE] 
> To replicate it, just use master and put debug print/breakpoint in following line:
> https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/5805f4c0078e24438edb931a9846f83674c22059/Cython/Compiler/PyrexTypes.py#L4775
> Both cases
> ```python
> import typing
> 
> def main(a: typing.Optional[Bar]):
>     pass
> ```
> and
> ```python
> import typing
> 
> def main(a: typing.Optional[None]):
>     pass
> ```
> contains value `[None]` in variable `template_values`.

Hence, when I want to avoid introducing `NoneType` we need to introduce major structural changes how annotation is evaluated at least in following function (which feeds `specilize_here()`:
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/5805f4c0078e24438edb931a9846f83674c22059/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py#L1254
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1277,6 +1277,9 @@ def coerce_to(self, dst_type, env):
             error(self.pos, "Cannot assign None to %s" % dst_type)
         return super().coerce_to(dst_type, env)
 
+    def analyse_as_type(self, env):
+        return py_none_type
+

Or implement the PR in totally different way, but in that case I have no idea how...

comment_data.body:
> this code gets literal `None` value for both cases:
> 
>     * `Union[int, None]`
> 
>     * `Union[int, DummyType]`

Then we need to make both distinguishable. A way to do that is to introduce `NoneType` as type and replace a literal `None` in type annotations with it.

I'm unsure whether that also applies to the `func() -> None` return type case, where the actual meaning is "has no return value" rather than "returns the constant value None". But it definitely applies to type declarations like the above.

Is there a reason, BTW, why we cannot represent `Union[xyz, None]` as `Optional[xyz]`, which we already support?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1277,6 +1277,9 @@ def coerce_to(self, dst_type, env):
             error(self.pos, "Cannot assign None to %s" % dst_type)
         return super().coerce_to(dst_type, env)
 
+    def analyse_as_type(self, env):
+        return py_none_type
+

comment_data.body: If we return something from a function, I prefer *always* returning something, i.e. explicitly `return None` otherwise here, not just implicitly. If that case is simply missing, the code makes me wonder if that's intended or whether something else was forgotten, and that distracts me from reading the code.

> Then we need to make both distinguishable. A way to do that is to introduce NoneType as type and replace a literal None in type annotations with it.

Yes, I think this PR is doing pretty that.

> I'm unsure whether that also applies to the func() -> None return type case, where the actual meaning is "has no return value" rather than "returns the constant value None". But it definitely applies to type declarations like the above.

I am not sure if it is important in context of Cython. In this PR Cython generates function which returns `PyObject *` value which is correct (I suppose)

> Is there a reason, BTW, why we cannot represent Union[xyz, None] as Optional[xyz], which we already support?

Honestly, the only reason is to more complete support of PEP 484.

             error(self.pos, "Cannot assign None to %s" % dst_type)
         return super().coerce_to(dst_type, env)
 
+    def analyse_as_type(self, env):
+        return py_none_type
+

comment_data.body: fixed.

Let's avoid the negation here.
```suggestion
    def analyse_as_type(self, env):
        if env.in_c_type_context:
            return None
        return py_none_type
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1279,6 +1279,11 @@ def coerce_to(self, dst_type, env):
             error(self.pos, "Cannot assign None to %s" % dst_type)
         return super().coerce_to(dst_type, env)
 
+    def analyse_as_type(self, env):
+        if not env.in_c_type_context:
+            return py_none_type
+        return None

comment_data.body: We can use parentheses here instead of a backslash.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -33,7 +33,7 @@
 from .Nodes import Node, SingleAssignmentNode
 from . import PyrexTypes
 from .PyrexTypes import c_char_ptr_type, py_object_type, typecast, error_type, \
-    unspecified_type
+    unspecified_type, py_none_type

comment_data.body:
We should also have tests here and for `cpdef` below that the `Union` and `Optional` declarations actually reject other types. Currently, we only test that they accept `tuple` and `None`, but not that they actually check the argument type at runtime. They could just do nothing.

I can see that there is a memoryview related test and another test for `float` further down, but we should try to cover some different kinds of argument types and all function types.
(The `float` test is even questionable because it unhelpfully rejects integers at runtime, but that's unrelated to this PR.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -34,57 +34,59 @@ def old_dict_syntax(a: list, b: "int" = 2, c: {'ctype': 'long int'} = 3, d: {'ty
     return a
 
 
-def pytypes_def(a: list, b: int = 2, c: long = 3, d: float = 4.0, n: list = None, o: Optional[tuple] = ()) -> list:
+def pytypes_def(a: list, b: int = 2, c: long = 3, d: float = 4.0, n: list = None, o: Optional[tuple] = (), v: Union[tuple, None]=()) -> list:

comment_data.body: Again, a negative test would show that the type declarations are not just no-ops.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -118,6 +118,18 @@ def ext_optional(x: typing.Optional[MyExtType], y: Optional[MyExtType]):
     """
     return attr(x) + attr(y)
 
+def ext_union(x: typing.Union[MyExtType, None], y: Union[None, MyExtType]):

comment_data.body:
The position of the parentheses here feel somewhat misleading to me. They are also not required. Let's just remove them and let the line separation work for us.
```suggestion
        return (
            self.modifier_name == 'typing.Optional' or
            self.modifier_name == 'typing.Union' and self.contains_none
        )
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4716,6 +4716,13 @@ class PythonTypeConstructorMixin:
     """Used to help Cython interpret indexed types from the typing module (or similar)
     """
     modifier_name = None
+    contains_none = False
+
+    def allows_none(self):
+        return (
+            self.modifier_name == 'typing.Optional' or (
+            self.modifier_name == 'typing.Union' and self.contains_none)
+        )

comment_data.body:
Shouldn't the name of the type be `NoneType`?
Is it ok that we don't define a `cname` here? (CPython uses the private name `_PyNone_Type`, which we certainly don't want to use.)
And why do you pass a list for the `objstruct_cname`?
```suggestion
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__('NoneType', cname=None)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4782,6 +4792,11 @@ def specialize_here(self, pos, env, template_values=None):
         # Replace this type with the actual 'template' argument.
         return template_values[0].resolve()
 
+class PyNoneType(BuiltinObjectType):
+
+    def __init__(self):
+        super().__init__('None', None, [])

comment_data.body: This is a rather unclear error message. We should try to keep the old one, or make the error detection explicit and reject it with a dedicated error message.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

+30:43: 'object' takes exactly one template argument.
+30:65: 'object' takes exactly one template argument.
+30:89: 'object' takes exactly one template argument.
+38:39: 'object' takes exactly one template argument.

comment_data.body: I think we should only set `contains_none` for `Union[]` declarations. This seems broader.

comment_data.body: What happens if a user writes `Optional[Union[int, None]]`? We'd probably get a duplicate `Optional` in that case, right? Although I'd guess that that won't even hurt us…
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3981,14 +3988,15 @@ def analyse_as_type(self, env):
 
     def analyse_pytyping_modifiers(self, env):
         # Check for declaration modifiers, e.g. "typing.Optional[...]" or "dataclasses.InitVar[...]"
+        # `typing.Optional` is used for all variants of modifiers representing Optional type (Optional[T], Union[T, None])
         # TODO: somehow bring this together with TemplatedTypeNode.analyse_pytyping_modifiers()
         modifiers = []
         modifier_node = self
         while modifier_node.is_subscript:
             modifier_type = modifier_node.base.analyse_as_type(env)
             if (modifier_type and modifier_type.python_type_constructor_name
                     and modifier_type.modifier_name):
-                modifiers.append(modifier_type.modifier_name)
+                modifiers.append('typing.Optional' if modifier_type.allows_none() else modifier_type.modifier_name)

commit.message: Use is_optional() only if type is PythonTypeConstructorMixin
Handle case when ttype is None

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

title: Add support of `typing.Union[XYZ, None]`
